main.opener: Sounds like you've had a lot going on lately, huh?

Yeah. Things really changed fast.
I leaked some files. About the BCI. About people who vanished.

Honestly, everything’s upside down now.
I used to believe in the BCI. I thought it kept order, kept us safe.
But I saw too much—people erased for tiny mistakes.
So I released the archive. All the records, all the abuses.
The moment people saw their own stories in those logs… trust just broke.
Returning residents started demanding answers. I became the outcast.
I can’t go anywhere without being watched now. But I couldn’t stay silent after what I saw.
Yeah, more than you know. I’m… not who most people think I am anymore.
I worked deep in the system, monitoring the patterns, believing we were keeping things fair.
The truth is, I saw the BCI’s dark side—people erased, lives ruined over… almost nothing.
When I released the abuse files and records of the disappeared, I became a pariah overnight.
Now, neighbors avoid me. My access is gone, my score is a warning sign.
Returned residents are demanding justice. Public anger is boiling over. Council’s turning on itself.
My life’s under total surveillance, but I did what I had to. I wanted people to see the truth, no matter what it cost me.
It’s a relief, in a way, to finally say it. Even if I’ve lost everything else.
main.emotion: Tired, but relieved to finally say something out loud.

emotional.opener: Oksana, you don’t have to hold it all in. It’s not wrong, wanting to speak up—everyone’s supposed to just keep quiet, but you shouldn’t carry that alone.
variants: Maybe. I don’t know. It just—gets heavy, sometimes.

I appreciate that. Sometimes it feels like I’m the only one who sees how much we’re all holding back.
There’s relief, honestly, in just saying it out loud.
It’s been a long time since anyone encouraged that.
Thank you. You have no idea how much it means to hear that from someone.
I’ve gotten used to watching every word, every movement.
Still, every day, the pressure builds and it’s exhausting.
Sometimes, I forget what it’s like to actually connect.
Hearing someone just acknowledge that helps.
Thank you. I spend so much energy trying to be invisible, to keep my head down.
It’s like everyone’s eyes are on me, weighing each choice I make.
Sometimes I wonder if I even remember how to relax, to be honest with anyone.
Back when I first started, I thought keeping quiet protected me—and maybe others, too.
Now, it just feels like I’m disappearing inside myself.
Having someone simply understand makes me feel a little more real again.
